paragraph: The Tale of Squirrel Nutkin Beatrix Potter
A STORY FOR NORAH
tokens: story

paragraph: BOOK 1.
This is a Tale about a tail--a tail that belonged to a little red squirrel, and his name was Nutkin.
tokens: tail tail belong little red squirrel name

paragraph: He had a brother called Twinkleberry, and a great many cousins: they lived in a wood at the edge of a lake.
tokens: have brother call great many cousin live wood edge lake

paragraph: In the middle of the lake there is an island covered with trees and nut bushes; and amongst those trees stands a hollow oak-tree, which is the house of an owl who is called Old Brown.
tokens: middle lake be island cover tree nut bush tree stand hollow oak tree house owl call old

paragraph: One autumn when the nuts were ripe, and the leaves on the hazel bushes were golden and green--Nutkin and Twinkleberry and all the other little squirrels came out of the wood, and down to the edge of the lake.
tokens: autumn nut ripe leave hazel bush golden green other little squirrel come wood edge lake

paragraph: They made little rafts out of twigs, and they paddled away over the water to Owl Island to gather nuts.
tokens: make little raft twig paddle water gather nut

paragraph: Each squirrel had a little sack and a large oar, and spread out his tail for a sail.
tokens: squirrel have little sack large oar spread tail sail

paragraph: They also took with them an offering of three fat mice as a present for Old Brown, and put them down upon his door-step.
tokens: take offering fat mouse present old put door step

paragraph: Then Twinkleberry and the other little squirrels each made a low bow, and said politely--
tokens: other little squirrel make low bow say

paragraph: "Old Mr. Brown, will you favour us with permission to gather nuts upon your island?"
tokens: old favour permission gather nut island

paragraph: But Nutkin was excessively impertinent in his manners. He bobbed up and down like a little red _cherry_, singing--
tokens: impertinent manners bobb little red _cherry_ sing

paragraph: "Riddle me, riddle me, rot-tot-tote!      A little wee man, in a red red coat!      A staff in his hand, and a stone in his throat;      If you'll tell me this riddle, I'll give you a groat."
tokens: riddle riddle rot tot tote little wee man red red coat staff hand stone throat tell riddle give groat

paragraph: Now this riddle is as old as the hills; Mr. Brown paid no attention whatever to Nutkin.
tokens: riddle old hill pay attention

paragraph: He shut his eyes obstinately and went to sleep.
tokens: shut eye go sleep

paragraph: The squirrels filled their little sacks with nuts, and sailed away home in the evening.
tokens: squirrel fill little sack nut sail evening

paragraph: But next morning they all came back again to Owl Island; and Twinkleberry and the others brought a fine fat mole, and laid it on the stone in front of Old Brown's doorway, and said--
tokens: next morning come other bring fine fat mole lay stone front old doorway say

paragraph: "Mr. Brown, will you favour us with your gracious permission to gather some more nuts?"
tokens: favour gracious permission gather more nut

paragraph: But Nutkin, who had no respect, began to dance up and down, tickling old Mr. Brown with a _nettle_ and singing--
tokens: have respect begin dance tickle old _nettle_ sing

paragraph: "Old Mr. B! Riddle-me-ree!      Hitty Pitty within the wall,      Hitty Pitty without the wall;      If you touch Hitty Pitty,      Hitty Pitty will bite you!"
tokens: old wall wall touch bite

paragraph: Mr. Brown woke up suddenly and carried the mole into his house.
tokens: wake carry mole house

paragraph: He shut the door in Nutkin's face. Presently a little thread of blue _smoke_ from a wood fire came up from the top of the tree, and Nutkin peeped through the key-hole and sang--
tokens: shut door face little thread blue _smoke_ wood fire come top tree peep key hole sing

paragraph: "A house full, a hole full!      And you cannot gather a bowl-full!"
tokens: house full hole full gather bowl full

paragraph: The squirrels searched for nuts all over the island and filled their little sacks.
tokens: squirrel search nut island fill little sack

paragraph: But Nutkin gathered oak-apples--yellow and scarlet--and sat upon a beech-stump playing marbles, and watching the door of old Mr. Brown.
tokens: gather oak apple yellow scarlet sit beech stump play marble watch door old

paragraph: On the third day the squirrels got up very early and went fishing; they caught seven fat minnows as a present for Old Brown.
tokens: third day squirrel get go fishing catch fat minnow present old

paragraph: They paddled over the lake and landed under a crooked chestnut tree on Owl Island.
tokens: paddle lake land crooked chestnut tree

paragraph: Twinkleberry and six other little squirrels each carried a fat minnow; but Nutkin, who had no nice manners, brought no present at all. He ran in front, singing--
tokens: other little squirrel carry fat minnow have nice manners bring present run front sing

paragraph: "The man in the wilderness said to me,     'How many strawberries grow in the sea?'      I answered him as I thought good--      'As many red herrings as grow in the wood.'"
tokens: man wilderness say many strawberry grow sea answer think good many red herring grow wood

paragraph: But old Mr. Brown took no interest in riddles--not even when the answer was provided for him.
tokens: old take interest riddle answer provide

paragraph: On the fourth day the squirrels brought a present of six fat beetles, which were as good as plums in _plum-pudding_ for Old Brown. Each beetle was wrapped up carefully in a dock-leaf, fastened with a pine-needle pin.
tokens: fourth day squirrel bring present fat beetle good plum _plum pudding_ old beetle wrap dock leaf fasten pine needle pin

paragraph: But Nutkin sang as rudely as ever--
tokens: sing

paragraph: "Old Mr. B! riddle-me-ree       Flour of England, fruit of Spain,       Met together in a shower of rain;       Put in a bag tied round with a string,     If you'll tell me this riddle, I'll give you a ring!"
tokens: old riddle fruit met shower rain put bag tie string tell riddle give ring

paragraph: Which was ridiculous of Nutkin, because he had not got any ring to give to Old Brown.
tokens: ridiculous get ring give old

paragraph: The other squirrels hunted up and down the nut bushes; but Nutkin gathered robin's pincushions off a briar bush, and stuck them full of pine-needle pins.
tokens: other squirrel hunt nut bush gather robin pincushion briar bush stick full pine needle pin

paragraph: On the fifth day the squirrels brought a present of wild honey; it was so sweet and sticky that they licked their fingers as they put it down upon the stone. They had stolen it out of a bumble _bees'_ nest on the tippitty top of the hill.
tokens: fifth day squirrel bring present wild honey sweet sticky lick finger put stone steal bumble _bee nest tippitty top hill

paragraph: But Nutkin skipped up and down, singing--
tokens: skip sing

paragraph: "Hum-a-bum! buzz! buzz! Hum-a-bum buzz!       As I went over Tipple-tine       I met a flock of bonny swine;     Some yellow-nacked, some yellow backed!       They were the very bonniest swine       That e'er went over Tipple-tine."
tokens: hum bum buzz buzz hum bum buzz go tine meet flock bonny swine yellow nack yellow back bonniest swine e 'er go tine

paragraph: Old Mr. Brown turned up his eyes in disgust at the impertinence of Nutkin.
tokens: old turn eye disgust impertinence

paragraph: But he ate up the honey!
tokens: eat honey

paragraph: The squirrels filled their little sacks with nuts.
tokens: squirrel fill little sack nut

paragraph: But Nutkin sat upon a big flat rock, and played ninepins with a crab apple and green fir-cones.
tokens: sit big flat rock play ninepin crab apple green fir cone

paragraph: On the sixth day, which was Saturday, the squirrels came again for the last time; they brought a new-laid _egg_ in a little rush basket as a last parting present for Old Brown.
tokens: sixth day squirrel come last time bring new laid _egg_ little rush basket last parting present old

paragraph: But Nutkin ran in front laughing, and shouting--
tokens: run front laugh shouting

paragraph: "Humpty Dumpty lies in the beck,      With a white counterpane round his neck,      Forty doctors and forty wrights,      Cannot put Humpty Dumpty to rights!"
tokens: lie beck white counterpane neck doctor wright put right

paragraph: Now old Mr. Brown took an interest in eggs; he opened one eye and shut it again. But still he did not speak.
tokens: old take interest egg open eye shut speak

paragraph: Nutkin became more and more impertinent--
tokens: become impertinent

paragraph: "Old Mr. B! Old Mr. B!     Hickamore, Hackamore, on the King's kitchen door;     All the King's horses, and all the King's men,     Couldn't drive Hickamore, Hackamore,     Off the King's kitchen door."
tokens: old old kitchen door horse man drive kitchen door

paragraph: Nutkin danced up and down like a _sunbeam_; but still Old Brown said nothing at all.
tokens: dance _sunbeam_ old say

paragraph: Nutkin began again--
tokens: begin

paragraph: "Arthur O'Bower has broken his band,      He comes roaring up the land!      The King of Scots with all his power,      Cannot turn Arthur of the Bower!"
tokens: break band come roar land power turn

paragraph: Nutkin made a whirring noise to sound like the _wind_, and he took a running jump right onto the head of Old Brown!...
tokens: make whirring noise sound _wind_ take running jump head old

paragraph: Then all at once there was a flutterment and a scufflement and a loud "Squeak!"
tokens: be flutterment scufflement loud squeak

paragraph: The other squirrels scuttered away into the bushes.
tokens: other squirrel scutter bush

paragraph: When they came back very cautiously, peeping round the tree--there was Old Brown sitting on his door-step, quite still, with his eyes closed, as if nothing had happened.
tokens: come peep tree be old sit door step eye close happen

paragraph: _But Nutkin was in his waistcoat pocket!_
tokens: waistcoat pocket

paragraph: This looks like the end of the story; but it isn't.
tokens: look end story

paragraph: Old Brown carried Nutkin into his house, and held him up by the tail, intending to skin him; but Nutkin pulled so very hard that his tail broke in two, and he dashed up the staircase and escaped out of the attic window.
tokens: old carry house hold tail intend skin pull tail break dash staircase escape attic window

paragraph: And to this day, if you meet Nutkin up a tree and ask him a riddle, he will throw sticks at you, and stamp his feet and scold, and shout--
tokens: day meet tree ask riddle throw stick stamp foot scold shout

paragraph: "Cuck-cuck-cuck-cur-r-r-cuck-k-k!"
THE END
tokens: end
